stem: A 29-year-old client with bipolar disorder is admitted with severe vomiting, ataxia (stumbling), and hand shaking. Based on the documentation in the Critical Lab Results & GI/Neuro Assessment tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute mental status changes and GI distress.
Background: Taking Lithium Carbonate for 2 years. Recently took Ibuprofen for back pain and reduced fluid intake due to 'stomach bug.'
Assessment: Client has an unsteady gait, slurred speech, and coarse tremors in both hands.
Recommendation: Stabilization of fluids and likely dialysis if level is critical.

tabs.title: Critical Lab Results
tabs.content:
TestFindingSignificance
Serum Lithium2.6 mEq/LCritical High (> 1.5 is toxic)
Serum Sodium132 mEq/L (Low)Risk factor for retention
Creatinine1.9 mg/dL (High)Acute Kidney Injury

tabs.title: Neuro Assessment
tabs.content: Presence of coarse tremors. Ataxic gait (positive Romberg). Confusion to time and place.

actionOptions.text: Immediately hold all scheduled doses of Lithium
Initiate IV 0.9% Normal Saline at 150 mL/hr
Administer an extra dose of Sodium Polystyrene (Kayexalate)
Administer Diazepam for alcohol withdrawal prevention

parameterOptions.text: Serial Serum Lithium and Creatinine levels
Lithium dose timing and peak flow meter

rationale.correct: The client is in severe Lithium Toxicity (c2) (Level 2.6). Symptoms include 'Coarse' tremors (unlike the 'Fine' tremors seen in side effects), ataxia, and slurred speech. risk factors include hyponatremia and NSAID use (Ibuprofen), both of which decrease renal clearance of Lithium. Priority actions: Stop the drug (a1) and flush the system with Normal Saline (a2) to help the kidneys excrete the lithium. Monitoring renal function/levels (p1) and neuro checks (p2) is vital.
clinicalPearls: NSAIDs (Ibuprofen, Naproxen) are CONTRAINDICATED with Lithium because they kidneys to retain the salt.
Low Sodium = High Lithium. The body sees Lithium as a sodium-substitute and grabs it if salt is low.

questionTrap.trap: Encouraging a low-sodium diet in this patient.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Wait! Low sodium makes Lithium toxicity worse. Lithium patients must maintain constant/adequate salt and fluid intake.

mnemonic.title: Toxicity Triad
mnemonic.expansion: G-Gait instability. I-Incessant N/V. N-Neuro (Coarse Tremors).
